title: nicola-sturgeon-say-today-covid-update-changes-announced
story: Nicola Sturgeon gave her weekly Covid update to Parliament today, during which she announced small scale changes to the vaccine passport scheme.However, these changes are not the anticipated expansion of the vaccine passport scheme, which the Scottish government has decided not to go ahead with.Last week, the first minister warned that vaccine passportscould be required in more venues like cinemas and theatres to help curb the spread of the virus over winter.But in todays announcement, sheconfirmedthat the Scottish government had decided expanding the scheme would not be necessary, instead announcing small changes to the current system which was introduced in October.Heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today.... The Scottish vaccine passport scheme will not be extendedThe Scottish vaccine passport scheme will notbe extended to include cinemas, theatres and other hospitality venues at the moment, the first minister confirmed.The news is likely to be welcomed by hospitality bosses who warned that the expansion of the scheme could cost venues customers.. Lateral flow tests can be used in place of vaccine passports from December From December , a negative lateral flow test can be used instead of a vaccine passport where proof of vaccination is required.People must currently prove they are fully vaccinated when attendingnightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.However, from Monday December , a negative lateral flow test will also be accepted for entry.It means that people can access such venues using either a vaccine passport or proof of a negative lateral flow test.. People to take lateral flow tests before any social situationThe Scottish government is asking everyone to take lateral flow tests before any form of socialisingto try and reduce the spread of the virus..removeThis is especially encouraged in the run up to the festive period when more people are likely to socialise.. Daily cases still hovering around , mark,new cases of COVID- were reported over past -hours and  new reported deaths.people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID- andpeople were in intensive care.Describing Scotlands position as more "positive" than we might have expected, the first minister warned that it was still"precarious" and urged people not to be "lulled into a  sense of security".She highlighted the deteriorating Covid situation in Europe as a reminder of the threat of the virus.. Information on boosters for + people and second vaccines for --year-olds comingInformation for people aged + on booking booster vaccines will be available soon, the first minister confirmed.Information on booking second vaccines will also become available for --year-olds soon.

title: world-famous-melrose-7s-return-covid-19-absence
story: Melrose Sevens is ing to the Greenyards in April  after missing from the event calendar for the last two years due to the Covid pandemic.The entertainment opens with a Sevens Hall of Fame Dinner on Thursday  April, attracting guests from the rugby world to celebrate some extraordinary people who will be inducted into Melrose Sevens Hall of Fame.On Friday  April, the rugby events start with a FOSROC Super game between the Southern Knights and the British Army. The evening will raise money and awareness for My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, with an exciting team of ex-internationalists and ex-Lions to compete in an exhibition Sevens game at half time.On Saturday  April, the traditional rugby sevens,  Centenary Cup will be played for by top-flight domestic and invitational sides, last won by London Scottish in .Phil Morris, Melrose Rugby Commercial and Sevens Tournament Director said, ldquoBeing able to attract quality teams to Melrose really does enable us to put this event on the world rugby sevens stage, a weekend of fantastic rugby that will continue to celebrate the traditions we all hold dear.Phil continued: ldquoWe want our Sevens tournament to be fun, therersquos going to be something for everyone, young and old. Melrose is where Rugby Sevens was invented in  and we will we be back with a bang in .The  Melrose Sevens event will start on the evening of Thursday  April, with a star-studded Hall of Fame Dinner to induct stars of the rugby sevens world.The rugby will start on Friday  April with a FOSROC Super Southern Knights game against the British Army under the floodlights on the G at the Greenyards. An evening of exciting top-flight rugby will be interspersed with global stars of the rugby world playing a charity Sevens match at half time to raise money and awareness for My Namersquo Doddie Foundation.The event will feature evening entertainment with Party Nights on Friday and Saturday for the music lovers, with tribute bands and DJs, tickets are pound..removeOn Saturday  April the  Centenary Cup, the traditional knockout Sevens we all know, and love will be played out by twenty teams from across Scotland and some exciting invitational teams.Our Sevens weekend will culminate on Sunday evening with a fantastic finale concert featuring Scottish bands, Bombskare and Big Country.Throughout the event the Triangle Fanzone will feature fast-food stalls, a large-tented bar and big screens.Phil added: ldquoMelrose and the local community have missed two sevens events due to Covid, and we are looking forward to being able to host our nd Sevens event that will draw people back to the Borders next year and it is exciting to be part of that.The club is delighted to be working with the support of Scottish Borders Council to ensure all logistics are managed.Designated seated tickets in the Main stand and Enclosure will be released soon. Anyone holding a ticket from the  event will be rolled over to April  and a new ticket will be issued.Ticket information - Thursday  April - Melrose Sevens Hall of Fame Dinner ndash poundFriday  April - Rugby ndash poundParty Night ndash poundSaturday  April - General EntryAdult ndash pound Concessions ndash pound Enclosure ndash pound- Main Stand ndash poundParty Night ndash poundSunday  April Finale Concert ndash pound

title: kelso-film-studio-plans-neglected-former-borders-church
story: A FORMER church in the Borders could be converted into a film studio after suffering years of ldquoneglect and decay.Production company Blue Mill Studios Ltd have filed the plans with the council for the ldquoimposing Trinity North structure in Kelso.The building was decommissioned by the Church of Scotland in the late s, according to papers submitted as part of the application.The report goes on to explain how the ownership of the ldquoGothic-style church changed hands a number of times before the production company bought it this year.:Witness appeal after man seriously injured in attack outside Borders barAccording to the plans, the major section of the church will be used as a studio in its ldquoun-restored form.The applicants also want to keep the B-listed building as a ldquomajor town feature by allowing community activities to be hosted there.The hall will be turned into ldquoa residential base for staff occupation,plans are approved.ldquoThis is a great and realistic opportunity following many  starts to ensure that this former church is retained and given le in the community, the papers state.ldquoThe works required to achieve this will not materially affect the quality of the original architecture to any great degree and it presents a great opportunity to enhance this long-neglected major building in Kelso.

title: galas-chance-put-town-football-map
story: ARGUABLY Gala Fairydean Roversrsquo biggest game of the season takes place on Saturday when League Two Annan Athletic visit Netherdale in the third round of the Scottish Cup.The winners will go into Monday nightrsquos draw along with the giants of Scottish football ndash and potentially a huge pay day could be the reward.Manager Neil Hastings is not underestimating the challenge ahead and is urging fans to create a good atmosphere and cheer the team onto victory.He told the Border : ldquoSaturday will be a huge challenge against a team who perform at a higher level."Itrsquos the biggest competition we play in, and we have the chance to reach the fourth round. Crowds have been improving recently and Irsquom hoping to see the local community turn out in their numbers for this chance to put the town on the football map. I know the players will relish a good atmosphere.The pair met last Boxing Day in the same competition and the visitors took the honours with a late goal and Hastings knows the task ahead.Hastings added: ldquoAs a manager I never stop thinking about the next game but Irsquove seen Annan a few times and had reports. I know it will be dficult as they have some good inidual players. We played them last year and since then they have added quality and depth to their squad. Theyrsquove been playing well and will be looking to get into the play-offs for promotion and are well-placed.Tickets cost pound  pound ndash pay at the gate. Us pound.

title: covid-scotland-can-use-england-covid-vaccine-passport-scotland
story: Proof of vaccination is required to attend some venues and events in Scotland, but are English Covid passes accepted With the festive period on the horizon and families travelling to visit loved ones, the matter of vaccine passports might crop up.While they are only required for international travel in England, in Scotland you must show that you are fully vaccinated to enternightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.So are English Covid passes valid in Scotland  Heres what you need to know...Are English Covid passes valid in Scotland Yes - English Covid vaccine passports are valid in Scotland.If you want to attend an event which requires proofof vaccination but received your jab in England, you can use your NHSapp to show that you are fully vaccinated.The same goes foryou received your vaccine in Wales - you can use your NHS app to show proof of vaccination.People who received the vaccine in Northern Ireland can useCovid NI to show proof of vaccination.Paper copies of proof of vaccine from these countries will also be accepted in Scotland.Are European vaccine passports accepted in Scotland Yes - the EU Digital Covid Certicate Scheme isaccepted as proof of vaccination in Scotland.What about for visitors outside the EU and UK Visitors from outside the EU and the UK who want to attend events in Scotland which require proof of vaccinationcan use the same certication they used to enter the country.Where are vaccine passports required in Scotland On Tuesday, the first minister confirmed that the vaccine passport scheme would not be extended, despite previous warnings.It means that vaccine passports are currently required in:nightclubsindoor live events with + people unseatedoutdoor live events with + peopleunseatedany event with ,+ people.removeHowever, from December , a negative lateral flow test will be accepted instead of a vaccine passport for entry to such venues.

title: see-christmas-lights-borders
story: CHRISTMAS lights are being turned on throughout the Scottish Borders from this week.Tonightin Melrose there will be music in the square between .pm and .pm to accompany the lights although there will be no formal switching on.Also at the Village Centre in West Linton from -pm to .pm there will be a special evening market with mulled wine, festive nibbles and live Christmas music. Local shops will be open late and the lights will be switched on at the Raemartin Square at pm.On Saturday in Kelso Town Square there will be dancers and music from pm along with hot chocolate non-alcoholic mulled wine fresh baked sweet mince pies home-made pork scratchings fairground rides for little ones and Santas Christmas treasure hunt. The lights will be switched on at pm.On Sunday in Peebles High Street people are invited to come along from pm to enjoy all delights of the Open Air Market. The Taylor Brothers will be live on stage from .pm with InChorus following on just shortly after. The Peebles Burgh Silver Band will play all the well-known Christmas Carols for the build-up to the Big Switch On at .pm.In Newtown St Boswells lsquoSwitch on Sundayrsquo takes place at the Newtown Community Wing Sprouston Road between noon and pm where people can browse at some craft stalls with cards, clothes and much more and also enjoy the ever popular raffle and tombola.On Sunday  December in Earlston there will be a parade from the Primary School at .pm with the lights being switched on at pm in the square whilst up the A in Lauder there will be an outdoor festival taking place pm -pm with Santarsquos grotto, street entertainment, Christmas jumper competition and face painting. The light will be switched on at pm.Other towns and villages in the region are still finalising plans.

title: garth-brooks-hails-unbelievable-news-five-croke-park-gigs
story: Garth Brooks has described the news that he will play five gigs in Croke Park next year as ldquounbelievable.A further three Dublin dates for the country superstar have been added due to demand from his Irish fan base.Tickets went on sale for his planned two concerts at Croke Park next September on Thursday morning.Within  minutes, an extra date was added to take place on Sunday September .At am, a further two dates were announced which will take place on Friday September  and Saturday September .Tickets went on sale immediately.Within minutes of the first two concerts going on sale at am, almost , people were waiting to snap them up.vw,vw,px, px"Country music star Garth Brooks on the roof of Croke Park in Dublin The demand for tickets could see all five concerts sell out.Croke Park was given permission by Dublin City Council to allow up to five gigs.Brooks tweeted in response: ldquoJust waking up to the news!!!!ldquoUnbelievable!!!!! All my love to you!!!The country music starrsquos five concerts in  were cancelled following a licensing dispute with local authorities.Dublin City Council said at the time that it would only grant licences for three of the concerts at the Dublin venue, however the singer refused to perform unless all five went ahead.In response to the extra dates for , a spokesperson for a residentsrsquo group near Croke Park said it is ldquounacceptable.Colm Stephens, from the Clonlfe and Croke Park Area Residentsrsquo Association, told RTE Radio rsquos Claire Byrne Show: ldquoWell we say what we have said all along, that we find this is unacceptable.ldquoThe basis for our reasoning is that this was investigated a long time ago by An Bord Pleanala and they imposed a cap on the number of concerts and the number of what are called lsquospecial eventsrsquo in the stadium. That cap was set to three per annum.# ##### #### ndash Due to demand, @garthbrookshas added an extra TWO dates at Dublins @CrokeParkon Friday  and Saturday  September .# Fri  Sept gtgtgt https:t.co xdJhJBTxi# Sat  Sept gtgtgt https:t.co xQGtEgKpic bbZiVfbqmdash Ticketmaster IrelandNovember , .removeldquoThree in any calendar year, we are prepared to accept and we feel that it is a reasonable compromise. Nothing has really changed in the circumstances. We think this cap should be followed.At a press conference in Dublin on Monday, Brooks said that while he would love to perform five gigs in the Drumcondra stadium, he ldquocanrsquot see it.ldquoIrsquod love to do five, but Irsquod also love to be ft in with abs, he told reporters.ldquoWhat happened in  was a miracle. Who does numbers like that  We got , hard tickets in one city and itrsquos impossible, therersquos no way we are going to do that number again. There is just no way.An emotional Brooks went on to say it was ldquoimpossible.He also said that his Irish fans will now have a chance to see him perform.ldquoWhat was meant to start this whole thing, is now going to be where this whole thing ends, he said.ldquoIf there is a blessing in what happened in that curse in , itrsquos the fact that there is a chance that this artist and those people, who are sweet enough to get tickets, now have a chance to see each other again..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Garth Brooks hails  uunbelievable u news of five Croke Park gigs

title: mammoth-ivory-pendant-earliest-eurasia-example-humans-decorating-jewellery
story: A ,-year-old oval-shaped ivory pendant made from mammoth bone represents the earliest known example of ornate jewellery made by humans in Eurasia, a new study suggests.Researchers analysed the pendant, found at the Stajnia Cave in Poland, in , along with an awl tool for hole-piercing made of horse bone.The pendant, awl and bone fragments were dated to the Early Upper Palaeolithic period .According to the scientists, the objects are the earliest known evidence of humans decorating jewellery in Eurasia and the emergence of the symbolic behaviour in human evolution.They used radiocarbon dating ndash a method for determining the age of an organic sample by measuring the amount of radioactive carbon present.Sahra Talamo, lead author of the study and director of the Bravho radiocarbon lab at the Department of Chemistry Giacomo Ciamician at Bologna University, said: ldquoDetermining the exact age of this jewellery was fundamental for its cultural attribution, and we are thrilled of the result.ldquoThis work demonstrates that using the most recent methodological advances in the radiocarbon method enables us to minimise the amount of sampling and achieve highly precise dates with a very small error range.ldquoIf we want to seriously solve the debate on when mobiliaryart emerged in Palaeolithic groups, we need to radiocarbon date these ornaments, especially those found during past fieldwork or in complex stratigraphic sequences.The pendant is decorated with more than  puncture marks in an irregular looping curve, and two complete holes.The pattern of indentations, similar to later jewellery found in Europe, could represent hunting tallies or lunar notations which correspond to the monthly cycle of the moon or sun, the researchers suggest.They also write that the presence of animal bones alongside the pendant and awl may indicate that humans were beginning to produce small and transportable art , years ago..removeCo-author Wioletta Nowaczewska of Wroclaw University, Poland, said: ldquoThis piece of jewellery shows the great creativity and extraordinary manual skills of members of the group of homo sapiens that occupied the site.ldquoThe thickness of the plate is about . millimetres showing an astonishing precision on carving the punctures and the two holes for wearing it.The study is published in Scientic Reports..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Mammoth ivory pendant  uearliest Eurasia example of humans decorating jewellery u

title: shops-closed-boxing-day-2021-scotland---see-full-list
story: The Boxing Day sales once saw thousands of people flock tothe high street, but this year many shops will keep their doors closed on December .With the increase in online shopping, lots of brands have decided to give their staff a well earned day off after Christmas.This includes some major supermarkets which is worth factoring in to your food shop before the big day so you can stock up on essentials.Heres what you need to know about which shops will be closed on Boxing Day ...Which shops are closed on Boxing Day in Scotland MorrisonsSainsburysAldiWaitroseMSIcelandHome BargainsWilkoArgosHabitatJohn LewisFat FacePoundlandPets at HomeThe EntertainerHolland and BarrettWhy are shops closing on Boxing Day In , many shops closed on BoxingDay as thank you to staff who had worked tirelessly through the pandemic.This year many stores will continue the new tradition of closing on December , giving employees a chance to take advantage of the festive break.Shops opening on Boxing Day has long been a controversial point, with a petition launched in  against shops opening on December  gathering over , signatures.The petition read: "Christmas is a family time, the one day is not enough time to see two sides of families, retail workers work extremely hard during the Christmas run up and only get the one day."If only everywhere could be closed boxing day! Some things are needed over the festive period, retail isnt one of them."It wasdebated in Parliament on December  , however the government concluded by saying: "We do not believe it is for the central Government to tell businesses how to run their shops or how best to serve their customers."Therefore we are not proposing to ban shops from opening on Boxing Day."

title: world-cup-play-off-draw-date-time-watch
story: The WorldCup play offdraw takes place on Friday, which will determine which teams will go head to head for a spot in the Qatar  World Cup.Thanks to Scotlands win against Denmarkin their final Group F match, they are seeded for the semi finals and will therefore face one ofAustria, North Macedonia, Turkey, Poland, Ukraine or Czech Republic.And Scotlandarent the only UK-seeded side -Wales have also secured a seeded spot.With the play-offs taking place next March, the draw will help Steve Clarkes side to prepare for what lies aheadas they try to move one step closer to Dohas World Cup.Having made it through to the play-off stageof Euro  earlier this summer, the team will look to build on this experience and move forward to win those all-important seats on the plane to Doha.Heres what you need to know about the World Cup play offdraw on Friday...When is the World Cup play offdraw The World Cup play offdraw will take place in Zurich, Switzerland at the Fa headquarterson Friday November  at pm UK time.How to watch World Cup play offdraw The World Cup play off draw can be livestreamed on Fas official website on Friday afternoon.Coverage will start at pm.When will the World Cup play offs take place The World Cup play offs are set to take place in March .The twelve teams in the draw will be ided into three groups to play semis and finals.Semi final matches will be played on March - , and finals on March - .The three winners of these finals will then qualy for the World Cup.Which teams are seeded for the World Cup play offs Scotland, Portugal, Italy, Russia, Sweden and Wales are all seeded for the World Cup play offs.Who could Scotland face in World Cup play offs Scotland and the other seeded sides could be drawn against any of the following teams:AustriaNorth MacedoniaTurkeyPolandUkraineCzech Republic.removeWhen does the  Qatar World Cup start The  World Cup will start on November  , with the final taking place on December  .This is later in the year than usual due to extremely high temperatures in Doha in the summer.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: new-mural-remembers-county-woman-accused-witchcraft
story: lsquoWitch  Were You rsquo was designed and painted by historian, artist and writer Charles Fletcher.The mural, completed last month, is on the front of MADE in East Lothianrsquos Arts Hub on Haddingtonrsquos Hardgate.It was commissioned by the art group as part of a community art project and funded by Haddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership .Charles, who is based in the Borders, said: ldquoThe mural is based on one of the only contemporary images of Scottish witches, a woodcut believed to have been produced in  by Mr James Carmichael, minister of Haddington.ldquoThe lsquowitchesrsquo in my mural are East Lothian residents. I wanted to commemorate the  accused by emphasising that they were ordinary people, and just like the residents of Haddington in .The mural is the second of its kind to find a home on Hardgate.The first mural was designed and painted by Musselburgh-based artist Laura Young and focused on John Knox.Artist Sasha Saben Callaghan, from Edinburgh, will create a third mural in the New Year.Charlesrsquos mural draws attention to  citizens of Haddington who were accused of witchcraft in the th and th centuries.At least  were found guilty and put to death.Fiona Lambert, director of MADE, said: ldquoToday, the town is a welcoming community and the MADE Arts Hub is a space for creative people who are mindful of each other, our neighbours, and the planet.For more information about the mural, go to charlesfletcher work haddingtonA QR code next to the mural also links to the notes.

title: teenagers-hand-rear-baby-goose-saved-cat
story: Friends Declan Longmuir, , and Keiron Rattray, , looked after the gosling they named Pip for six months after rescuing her from the felinersquos clutches in May.They released her back into the River Esk at Musselburgh earlier this month.The friends were walking along the river in May when they spotted a black cat with the chick in its mouth.Declan, a former Preston Lodge High School pupil who now lives in Fisherrow, said: ldquoWe ran after it and the cat dropped the gosling and ran off.Keiron, a former pupil of Musselburgh Grammar School who has experience helping and raising animals through voluntary work with the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals , picked up the chick and they took it home.Declan said: ldquoWe tried phoning the SSPCA but, because it was a foreign bird, they couldnrsquot touch it or do anything with it as they only cover native animals.The pair kept the badly injured bird inside for the first three weeks until the scars on her head and neck were healed enough for her to go outside.She then enjoyed living in the garden with chickens, who took their feathered friend to their hearts.Six months on, they decided Pip was strong enough to go it alone in the wild again and released her into the River Esk on November .Declan said: ldquoWe didnrsquot really want to leave her side but it was getting late so we decided to pop back the next morning and check on her.ldquoSeeing her with her new goose friends made us really happy and proud of the goose she had become.ldquoIrsquom just glad that Pip survived for all she has been through as a chick.Sarah Gregory, SSPCA chief inspector, said: ldquoCanadian geese are classed as a non-native species by the UK Government. If an injured Canadian goose is reported to us we will attend but we would not be able to release the goose back into the wild as we do not have the necessary permissions. If we did rescue a Canadian goose, we would have to euthanise it as we are bound by the law.ldquoWe would not recommend anyone other than an expert hand-rearing a wild animal.ldquoIf anyone finds a sick or injured animal, please report it to our animal helpline on   .

title: home-plans-submitted-former-chicken-barn
story: Plans to breathe new le into the farm building between Garvald and Morham are being considered by East Lothian Council.The sheds were used as lsquodeep-penrsquo laying barns, in which the hens were housed on the first floor, with a void at ground level below.A design statement submitted to the local authorityrsquos planning department outlines the proposals from Richard and Sharon Bolton for Chesters Farm.It reads: ldquoThe sheds are currently in poor condition and no longer compatible with modern farming techniques or reuse as farming buildings.ldquoThe proposal seeks to convert the barn into a contemporary family home.Drawings with the application show vehicles could be parked under the property, with four bedrooms on the first floor. Terraces would be formed to the south and east and the lower area retained as storage.

title: community-group-hunt-volunteers-upcoming-social-events
story: The townrsquos events group has been sidelined due to the coronavirus pandemic but the group is now looking to the future and the situation was discussed by the townrsquos community council last Tuesday.A spokesperson for the group, which also covers Athelstaneford, said: ldquoHaddington Events Group is looking for volunteers."If anybody knows anybody, letrsquos start planning for the Haddington Festival for next year.

title: speeding-motorcyclist-drove-astonishing-120mph-a1
story: Richard Montgomery, , was racing away from a BMW along the busy A while on board his Suzuki bike when he was caught travelling mph above the legal limit of mph last year.Traffic police stationed on an overhead bridge spotted Montgomery speeding near to the Gladsmuir Junction of the main road and gave chase.The officers eventually managed to catch up with the Scout leader and he was arrested and charged with dangerous driving.Montgomery, of High Street, appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last month, where he admitted driving at a ldquogrossly excessive speed on September  last year.He was back in the dock for sentencing on Monday, where Sherf Matthew Auchincloss described the speed he reached as ldquoastonishing.Solicitor Kevin Connor told the court: ldquoFirst of all, there is excuse for what he did. His position is that he was being tailgated by a BMW and he took the silly decision to accelerate away from it.ldquoWhat he did was way overboard and there was no need to accelerate to the speed he did, but he did and he accepts his guilt.ldquoHe understands what he did was risky and dangerous. He did slow down of his own accord very soon afterwards.The lawyer added that Montgomeryrsquos illegal behaviour on the road was ldquovery brief, as he was clocked doing mph at .pm and then pulled over and charged by the police at .pm.Mr Connor said that Montgomery was a local Scout leader and that he owned a golf chauffeur business, Montgomery Golf Ltd, where he drove mainly American tourists to play at prestigious golf courses throughout Scotland.The court also heard that Montgomery had previous driving convictions on his record and that he currently had live penalty points on his licence.Sherf Auchincloss said: ldquoThe speed you were doing was astonishing.ldquoThe level of risk to you and to other road users was very high indeed.The sherf banned Montgomery from driving for  months and ordered him to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community as an alternative to a custodial sentence.The businessman was also told he must complete the extended driving test before he is allowed back on the road.Montgomery pleaded guilty to driving a motorcycle dangerously and at grossly excessive speeds at the A near Gladsmuir on September  last year.

title: nicola-sturgeon-say-today-covid-update-changes-announced
story: However, these changes are not the anticipated expansion of the vaccine passport scheme, which the Scottish government has decided not to go ahead with.Last week, the first minister warned that vaccine passportscould be required in more venues like cinemas and theatres to help curb the spread of the virus over winter.But in todays announcement, sheconfirmedthat the Scottish government had decided expanding the scheme would not be necessary, instead announcing small changes to the current system which was introduced in October.Heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today...The Scottish vaccine passport scheme will notbe extended to include cinemas, theatres and other hospitality venues at the moment, the first minister confirmed.The news is likely to be welcomed by hospitality bosses who warned that the expansion of the scheme could cost venues customers.From December , a negative lateral flow test can be used instead of a vaccine passport where proof of vaccination is required.People must currently prove they are fully vaccinated when attendingnightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.However, from Monday December , a negative lateral flow test will also be accepted for entry.It means that people can access such venues using either a vaccine passport or proof of a negative lateral flow test.The Scottish government is asking everyone to take lateral flow tests before any form of socialisingto try and reduce the spread of the virus.This is especially encouraged in the run up to the festive period when more people are likely to socialise.,new cases of COVID- were reported over past -hours and  new reported deaths.people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID- andpeople were in intensive care.Describing Scotlands position as more "positive" than we might have expected, the first minister warned that it was still"precarious" and urged people not to be "lulled into a  sense of security".She highlighted the deteriorating Covid situation in Europe as a reminder of the threat of the virus.Information for people aged + on booking booster vaccines will be available soon, the first minister confirmed.Information on booking second vaccines will also become available for --year-olds soon.

title: 200-seater-stand-football-fans-approved
story: The club has been enjoying bumper crowds at New Countess Park, with fans delighted to be back cheering on their team after a season ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic.A debut Scottish Cup run has boosted numbers through the gates and the club has now been given the green light to build the stand at its home ground.Stuart Robertson, chairman of the East of Scotland Football LeaguePremier Division outfit, was delighted with the news.Attention now turns to finding pound, to cover the cost of the stand, and Stuart said: ldquoIt is just pressing on with the hard work to raise the remainder of the funds.ldquoWe have made good progress and the board is incredibly confident it will be a reality but there is still quite a lot of work to do.ldquoWe are about halfway there with the fundraising.The stand will also include a covered area for disabled supporters.A concrete foundation will be put in place before the stand is then built along the touchline.The club chairman stressed that the actual construction of the stand was not a long process and, when money was in place, it would take only a matter of weeks to be finished.The number of spectators through the gate has risen on the previous season when fans could cheer on their team.Stuart told the Courier it put them towards the top of the EoSFL table, alongside title-chasing Penicuik Athletic and Tranent Juniors, as well as heavyweights Musselburgh Athletic and Linlithgow Rose.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved the proposals, which also won support from the townrsquos community council, earlier this month.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire welcomed the announcement and felt it was a sign of the club progressing.He said: ldquoI think it is fantastic.ldquoIt will be a major improvement to the ground and it will be really welcomed by the older spectators that Dunbar has because it will give them a seat to sit in, watch the game and shelter from any wild weather in the winter months.ldquoThe club is really moving itself into a really professional set up.East Lothian MSP Paul McLennan, who is also a Dunbar ward councillor, was previously involved with the youth academy at Hibernian Football Club.He was ldquoabsolutely delighted for the Seasiders and said: ldquoThe club has shown fantastic ambition in developing the proposals, after doing so well in its first Scottish Cup ties this year.ldquoI wish to pay special thanks to the late Malcolm Jones, father of the previous Dunbar United manager Geoff Jones. Malcolm put a lot of work into the development of the idea ndash perhaps naming the stand after him would be a fitting tribute.Finally, Dunbar ward councillor Sue Kempson described it as ldquoa positive step.She said: ldquoI am very pleased they have got somewhere for their fans to sit and watch the games in comfort.ldquoMy initial reaction is this seems like a very good idea and I am very pleased for them.ldquoThey are a very active club and the more they can improve the better.

title: merryhatton-gardening-column-choosing-christmas-tree
story: The debate about real vs fake trees has been ongoing for many years and this month we decided you might like an update on current thinking.Many environmental groups, including the Soil Association, the Woodland Trust and the Carbon Trust, recommend real trees over articial ones and itrsquos important to understand why because what you do with your tree can make quite a dference. Letrsquos look at the dferent stages in the le of both types of trees.Real treesThe growing time for real trees is approximately - years to reach the most popular size of  ft . During that time, they provide habitat for wildle, capture carbon from the atmosphere, stabilise ground that is often unsuitable for other uses and reduce water run-off that can cause erosion.With estimated sales of in excess of seven million real trees sold in the UK every year, itrsquos clear that forestry also provides much-needed rural employment.You donrsquot need to worry about deforestation either: Christmas trees are a renewable resource, generally grown as a crop with up to  trees being planted for every two-metre tree that is cut down, ensuring that the environmental benefits of woodland are maintained and potentially even improved.As the seedling grows into a tree, itrsquos clear that real trees make positive benefits to our environment but once that tree leaves the forest or the nursery, your choices begin to matter.How can you help the environment  The first step is easy: buy a Scottish-grown tree from a local business and you minimise the carbon miles from the forest to your home.Most reputable garden centres in the area should be able to offer you a Scottish-grown tree, but other outlets may not. We recommend that you check the source before you buy!But itrsquos what happens to the tree after Christmas where you can make a real dference. Research shows that the way in which the tree is disposed of has considerably dferent environment effects.At one end of the spectrum, landfill is the worst possible solution for disposing of your Christmas tree, since decomposition and the release of methane negatively impact on the environment. Surprisingly, even burning the tree is preferable to landfill as that reduces potential emissions by over  per cent.At the other end of the spectrum, one of the most environmentally friendly solutions is to reuse the tree by chipping it for mulch or to compost it.Chipping simply accelerates the plant cycle that would occur naturally on the forest floor.This non-chemical process helps the tree break down more quickly than it otherwise would in the forest, naturally ing fibre and nutrients to the soil.Local authorities often offer a collect and chip service, and East Lothian Council have done so for a number of years now.Articial treesArticial trees, it is argued, are environmentally friendly because they can be re-used year after year and, for many, itrsquos the ideal solution for reasons of practicality and convenience. In fact, the key to determining whether an articial or a real tree is more environmentally friendly lies in the number of times you use the articial tree. Letrsquos consider the factors.Most articial trees are manufactured in China using plastic, PVC and metal, and these are then shipped to consumers around the world.The materials used in production and the global shipping distances involved in delivery combine to result in a considerable negative environmental impact from articial trees.And whilst the tree can be reused year after year, there still remains the problem of disposal at the end of its le articial trees are not recyclable and inevitably end up in landfill.According to the Carbon Trust, the carbon footprints for a m tree are:l Articial tree ndash kgl Real tree to landfill ndash kgl Real tree, chipped ndash .kg.Therefore, their advice is that you need to re-use your articial tree more than  times to equal the carbon footprint of a real tree that is responsibly disposed of. Many articial trees are not built to last that long and soyou decide that an articial tree is best for your lestyle, try to buy one that genuinely can be reused over at least  years.In conclusionCaring for our environment is a complex matter, andit only involved a single issue ndash such as the carbon footprint figures above ndash decisions would be easy. But itrsquos rarely that simple you only need to think about the many iables mentioned in this article to understand the complexity of the decisions we all have to make.We hope that this article offers you a brief overview that will help you decide which type of tree is best for you.As always, our plant team are happy to discuss the options with you and help you decide what tree ndash real or articial ndash is best for you.Theyrsquore also able to explain how you can get the very best from your tree and enjoy it throughout the Christmas season.

title: paralympian-leads-opening-brewerys-brand-new-visitor-experience
story: Paralympic Games medallist Maria Lyle, who lives in Dunbar, was joined by members of Dunbar Royal British Legion Pipe Band and East Lothian Provost John McMillan on November  to officially open the facility at Belhaven Brewery.The breweryrsquos visitor experience will give people an opportunity to discover the history of Scotlandrsquos oldest working brewery, which dates back to , learn the brewing process of Belhavenrsquos beers and see the locally sourced malt used in the brewing process.Fiona Matheson, Belhaven Brewery marketing executive, has been leading on the project and was delighted to see the experience open.She said: ldquoIt has been a real collective team effort to get the visitor experience into the position it is in today.ldquoAt Belhaven, we are proud of our people, our place and our products and this visitor experience tells an exceptional story of all three of those things.ldquoAs Scotlandrsquos oldest working brewery, we have so many stories to tell and hope visitors to our home will be captured by everything that Belhaven has to offer.The brewery, which is famous for beers including Belhaven Best, Belhaven Black and Belhaven  Shilling, will allow people to enjoy a tutored tasting of four award-winning Belhaven Beers.The experience will also enable visitors to have their picture taken in front of Belhavenrsquos iconic chimneys and visit the secret garden.Mr McMillan, who is also East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, enjoyed the tour.He said: ldquoIt was an amazing experience and the whole visit encapsulated everything Belhaven and East Lothian has to offer.ldquoWe are proud to be Scotlandrsquos Food and Drink County and Belhaven is just one of the wonderful local businesses that show why East Lothian deserves that title.ldquoWe are proud to have Scotlandrsquos oldest working brewery in East Lothian and I would encourage everyone from Scotland and beyond to come and experience the history and taste of Belhavenrsquos beers as soon as possible.

title: winter-wanderland-festive-window-displays-light-town
story: Organised by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, the winter display event invites residents to create illuminated displays in their gardens, windows or doors to light up the streets.Residents taking part should email their name and address to cockenzieandportseton@hotmail by December  to register their interest.A map will then be produced showing the locations of all the displays, forming an after-sunset walking trail.Prizes will be awarded to the best displays, with judging taking place on Wednesday, December .

title: wooden-christmas-cabins-return-town-centre
story: Wooden cabins were located around the town centre last December in a bid to help drum up business for traders who had suffered a challenging year due to the coronavirus pandemic.The cabins will again find a home in the town, on Court Street outside the townrsquos Corn Exchange, which is currently closed.Paul Kinnock, from Haddington Business Community Partnership , confirmed work was well under way ahead of Christmas.He said: ldquoDue to the success of last yearrsquos event and positive feedback, the promotions group are having the festive cabins and market from November .ldquoThe purpose of the cabins is to assist with town centre recovery and increase footfall in the town centre over the festive period.ldquoThere was great feedback from a survey of the general public last year and this will be built upon.The cabins will be in place on November  alongside the monthly Haddington Farmersrsquo Market and will also open the following day to coincide with the townrsquos Christmas lights switch-on.A iety of businesses, including arts and crafts makers, will set up home in the cabins, which will then be open from Thursday to Sunday each week in the lead-up to December .Last year, the cabins, which were located on Court Street, Lodge Street and neighbouring High Street, were in place until pm on Christmas Eve.Traders sold everything from jewellery and arts and crafts to beer and pies.Mr Kinnoch confirmed that would be the case once again this festive season.He stressed it was about ldquocomplementing other businesses in the town rather than competing with them, and the cabins would help attract more people to the town centre.As well as the cabins, HBCP is distributing leaflets to every house in Haddington, Gford and Athelstaneford to make them aware of the plans for the town.Banners encouraging people to shop locally will be put in place at each of the entrances to Haddington, while the annual Christmas window competition has also been launched.Ward councillor John McMillan, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for tourism and economic development, felt businesses had benefited from the special Christmas programme last year.He said: ldquoI hope the idea will grow.ldquoThere are talks about other markets in the town and things happening for Christmas.ldquoAll that is good to promote a vibrant town centre.

title: christmas-bargains-grabs-table-top-sale
story: The fundraiser, which is held from noon to pm next Sunday , is in East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club.Various stalls will be in place, with the chance for people to get their Christmas shopping started.Tea and coffee will also be on sale and admission is free of charge.

title: pupils-photos-feature-2022-calendar
story: The calendar, with winning photos from a school photography competition, is now on sale, priced pound.Pupils from  classes took part in the competition on the theme lsquoSomething That Makes You Smilersquo.The overall winner was lsquoSunset In The Harbourrsquo, by Romilly Upcraft, P, which appears on the front page of the Burgh Primary  calendar.The other winners were: lsquoBarbies and My Friend Jackrsquo by Clara Bose, nursery lsquoThere Are Eggs Under There!rsquo by Anna Thomson, P lsquoDaffodil Picturersquo by Vinnie Dunn, P lsquoEtta In The Parkrsquo by Lily Doherty, P lsquoI Love Ice Creamrsquo by Caroline McDonough, P  lsquoPeek A Baarsquo by Ava Virlogeux, P lsquoBassie The Guillemotrsquo by Ophelia Carter, P  lsquoHeidirsquo by Lily Fisher, P lsquoSpring Bunniesrsquo by Erica Olds, P  lsquoBooks Hearts and Flowersrsquo by Anya Peet, P lsquoWinter Wonderlandrsquo by Angus Ross, P and lsquoThe Bridges rsquo by Lauren Hollingsworth, P.The children have been asked what they would like to see in the playground and new play equipment is being costed.Family and friends of the Burgh will be able to purchase the calendar via SchoolPay at the Love Musselburgh Christmas shopping and crafts day at St Michaelrsquos Church Hall, Dalrymple Loan, on Saturday, from am and via the parent council Facebook page lsquoMusselburgh Burgh Parent Councilrsquo.The parent council will launch a Christmas raffle shortly and it is hoped that local businesses will give support as part of their community funding schemes.

title: east-lothian-weather-strong-wind-cause-disruption-across-county
story: The warning begins at am on Friday and runs until pm on Saturday.As well as covering all of East Lothian, the warning covers the whole of Scotland and Northern Ireland.A period of very strong winds are set to develop across northern Scotland on Friday afternoon then extend south during the evening.Delays on roads and rail arelikely.

title: east-lothian-school-term-dates-next-three-years-set
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos education committee agreed the dates for school sessions for the   year through to the   year at a virtual meeting on Tuesday.Members were told that City of Edinburgh Council had already set its term dates for the next three years and matching the dates was the preferred option for the "vast majority" of people consulted in recent years in the county.The committee was told that among the points included to mirror the city dates were:afixed one-week break in the third week of October the school session ending before the first full week of July fivefixed in-service days and flexibility with the Easter break to allow for a natural end to term two.The report to council was written before Midlothian Council agreed its dates for the next three years at a meeting last week and did not includedetails.Midlothian also opted to align with the City of Edinburgh and Lothian neighbours as much as possible.The committee agreedthe new dates for the next three years.The East Lothian dates for  , which remain open for change, will see the school year start for pupils on Wednesday, August , with the October break from Friday, October , to Tuesday, October , and term end for Christmas on Tuesday, December .Schools willon Wednesday, January , with a break from Friday, February , to Tuesday, February , for pupils and the Easter break from Friday, March .Term three restarts for pupils on Monday, April , and ends on Wednesday, June .School year for   starts on Wednesday, August , for pupils, with the Octoberbreak from Friday, October , to Tuesday, October .The schools will then break for Christmas on Friday, December , , ing for term two on Monday, January .Mid-term break will be from Friday, February , , to Tuesday, February , with the Easter break from Thursday, March .Term three  resumes on Tuesday, April , with the schoolyear finishing on Friday, June .The   year will start on Wednesday, August , withthe Octoberbreak from Friday, October , to Tuesday, October , and term ending on Friday, December .Term two  begins on Monday, January , with mid-term break from Friday, February , to Tuesday, February , and Easter break on Friday, April .Termthree restarts on Tuesday, April , with the  school year ending on Thursday, June.Full details, including staff in-service days and public holidays, will be made available on the East Lothian Council website.

title: east-lothian-covid-cases-rise-25-per-cent
story: East Lothian had  cases of Covid- between November  and , giving a seven-day positive rate per , people of ..This is far higher than the figures for the previous weekwhen  positive Covid- cases were recorded, producing a seven-day positive rate per , people of ..RankingsEast Lothian now has the sixth highest Covid rate in Scotland, with Falkirk top .Neighbouring City of Edinburghand Midlothian Councilboth have seven-day rates per , people signicantly lower than East Lothianrsquos. In the county, Haddington Rural, which includes Gford, recorded the most cases in the last seven days , giving it a seven-day rate of ..Every town and village in East Lothian reported six or more Covid cases between November  and , with one Covid related death recorded in the last seven days bringing the total of virus related deaths in the county to .TownsListed below is a breakdown of case numbers in each part of East Lothian:Haddington Rural ndash  cases, seven-day positive rate of .Cockenzie ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Dunbar West ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Haddington North ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Gullane and Drem ndash  cases, seven-day rate .East Linton and rural ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Ormiston ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Dunbar East ndash  cases, seven-day rate ..Tranent South ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Musselburgh East ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Musselburgh South ndash  cases, seven-day rate Haddington South ndash  cases, seven-day rate .North Berwick South ndash  cases, seven-day rate .North Berwick North ndash  cases, seven-day rate Pinkie Braes ndash  cases, seven-day rate Wallyford Whitecraig ndash  cases, seven-day positive rate of .Prestonpans East ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Musselburgh North ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Longniddry and Aberlady ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Tranent North ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Prestonpans West ndash  cases, seven-day rate .Musselburgh West ndash  cases, seven-day rate .VaccinationsMeanwhile, the vast majority of East Lothian residents have now received both doses of a coronavirus vaccine.As of yesterday , , people over the age of  have received their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine.This equals . per cent of the population.A total of , people have received their second dose, or . per cent of the population.And , residents or . per cent have received a third dose or booster coronavirus vaccine.

title: anxiety-covid-19-preventing-east-lothian-children-attending-school
story: Education chiefs say that while the majority of pupils in the county successfully ed to classrooms following closures, lockdowns had had a detrimental impact on some, with a ldquosmall cohort still unable to .And despite warning that schools would be living with the impact of the pandemic for years to come, education chiefs said that they had set a goal of ing to pre-pandemic attainment levels by the end of the current school year.A report to East Lothian Councilrsquos education committee on the Covid recovery by schools revealed that there were stillongoing issues.Committee members raised concerns about ongoing ventilation issues in classrooms, as pupils face another chilly winter with windows remaining open regardless of the weather.And it was revealed that the local authoritywas having to pull cleaning staff from other public services to cover a ldquosevere shortfall in cleaners to ensure schools remained open.Despite this, Nicola McDowell, head of education, told the committee that staff were hopeful pupils would be ready to take exams next year, with prelim plans already in place, as teachers were praised for their hard work.In her report to the committee, she said her departmentrsquos aspiration was that ldquoby the end of this session,attainment s to pre-pandemic levels.Scottish Government funding of pound.million has been allocated to the local authority to support recovery and will be used to tackle ldquolost learning.The committee was told that some children had fallen behind while others were still not in class.The report said: ldquoWhile most children and young people have managed toto in-schoollearning, there is still a small cohort whose anxiety has caused a barrier to their .ldquoSchool staff and staff from our inclusion and wellbeing service continue to work proactively with them and their families to ensure they aresupported and continue to learn.The number of children struggling with anxiety was not available, although it is understood it includes pupils across primary and secondary schools in the county.Dr Lynne Binnie, educational psychologist, told the committee that a team was in place to offer support to those who were struggling.She said: ldquoOur early intervention team which sits between education and child services has been operating for a few weeks and we are working to ensure we can use every bit of potential funding we can get to support our young people.The committee was told that it had been decided to continue with restrictions such as face masks for secondary school pupils and staff, and restricting visitors to schools after the October holiday, and that guidance had been confirmed by the Scottish Government this week.Education bosses have also decided to have no residential trips in this school year.Concern over the continued policy of opening windows and doors in classrooms to ventilate them in winter were raised.Councillor John Williamson asked what provisions the schools had to support a child whose parent either could not provide warm clothing or had forgotten.Warm clothingHe said: ldquoSome parents are not able to provide warm clothing ndash unfortunately it still happens ndash or they may be rushing out of the door and forget.However, Sarah Morgan, Pencaitland Primary School headteacher, told the committee: ldquoAt our school we have a range of pre-loved unorms available at any time which we can use to support any child who needs it and I am sure all schools have these pre-loved unorm banks as well.The report concluded that schools and pupils would be living with the impact of the pandemic ldquofor years to come.However, it added: ldquoSchools and the wider education service will do everything we can to mitigate this impact, learn the lessons of what has worked and what we need to improve and ensure that we continue to improve outcomes for all.Paul McLennan, East Lothian MSP and a councillor for the Dunbar and East Linton ward, said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic has caused unprecedented challenges for all of us in East Lothian, but children and young people have undoubtedly been some of the most affected.ldquoThere is a growing body of evidence which suggests Covid- has had a signicant strain on the mental health and wellbeing of Scotlandrsquos children and young people.ldquoDisruption caused by lockdowns and levels of uncertainty around the future will have of course caused lasting impact.ldquoAs we move forward from this pandemic, supporting our children and young people with their mental health and well-being must continue to be a priority.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, added: ldquoLockdown has been hard on the young ndash normal le and even rites of passage restricted.ldquoItrsquos not simply in schooling but in le that itrsquos occurred.ldquoNo wonder many have struggled.ldquoSome restrictions need to remain for the wellbeing of all ages but especially the young, who are not invulnerable.ldquoBut additional support for those who have been facing dficulties and challenges is required and as much normality as is possible is required for all.

title: christmas-gifts-offer-haddington-farmers-market-saturday
story: Haddington Pipe Band and Clark Community Choir will also be providing entertainment at the market, which forms part of East Lothianrsquos Saltire Festival.A wide range of seasonal produce from beetroot and Brussels sprouts to pumpkin and parsnips will be on offer, as well as a range of meats, chutneys, pies and preserves.Local grower Letham Plants will have a selection of wreaths and seasonal plants, while there will also be handmade soap and locally designed screen prints.The Woodland Trust will be on hand to explain how trees can help combat the climate crisis in its Big Climate Fightback campaign.East Coast Buses will bring one of its vehicles to promote contactless travel and local bus services.The market will be running from am to pm on Court Street.

title: public-consulted-plans-meeting-centre-people-dementia-musselburgh
story: East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership is working with Musselburgh Area Partnership, Dementia Friendly East Lothian, Open Arms Carers and Outside the Box to develop the new facility.A spokesperson for the project said: ldquoEveryone is invited to share their views on activities and supports for the meeting centre, and the things which are important to people living with dementia.Members of the public can speak to staff from Outside the Box near the box office at The Brunton todayuntil .pm and tomorrowfrom .am to .pm.They will also be at Musselburgh Library on Monday and next Wednesday from am to noon.For more information and ways to get involved, contact Sue Northrop, of Dementia Friendly East Lothian, by emailing sue@dfel.org.uk or phoning   .

title: east-lothian-schoolchildren-produce-special-film-screened-cop26-green-zone
story: Innerwick, Longniddry, Macmerry and Dunbar Primary Schools worked with D Fie Foe film company and well-known East Lothian musician David Trouton to create an environmentally themed animated film, featuring the childrenrsquos voices and artwork.Exploring the environment around them through lsquowalking storiesrsquo, the children helped to create the film ndash Sound Story ndash entirely outdoors.It was funded by East Lothian Youth Music Initiative, East Lothian Council Arts Service and Screen Scotland.COP, the United Nations climate change conference, took place in Glasgow earlier this month.The Green Zone was where the public, civil society, indigenous peoples, youth groups, charities, academics, artists and businesses could get their voices heard through a programme of events, workshops, talks and exhibitions.The film has also been shortlisted for the Scottish Youth Film Foundation Festival, and all  finalist films will be added to the Scottish National Library Moving Image Archive.Sound Story also featured as part of East Lothianrsquos  Harbours Festival in July.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, cabinet spokesperson for community wellbeing, said: ldquoCongratulations to our primary school pupils for creating this inspiring animation.ldquoA truly collaborative production between all involved and a fantastic way for our young people to get involved with a COP event.ldquoEast Lothian Councilrsquos Arts Service and Youth Music Initiative East Lothian provide opportunities for our schools to access high-quality arts experiences and creative projects such as this.ldquoI am delighted that this film has been shortlisted for the Scottish Youth Film Foundation Festival and is must-see viewing for all.Principal teacher Aileen Kelly and P pupil Euan Kelly, age , from Dunbar Primary School, attended the screening in Glasgow representing all the young filmmakers from East Lothian.Aileen said: ldquoThe screening in the IMAX cinema was super, and the quality of the films from all  finalists was incredible. We felt really privileged to be there, and to have been involved in something so worthwhile. We would like to thank Jonathan, Dave and Simonefor all their work with our school during the project.The pupils across the schools loved the experience of taking part and reported: ldquoWe thought it was awesome ldquoIt was great to see our own art work animated and we loved the voice over ldquoIt was exciting to see our name in the credits ldquoWe put so much effort in ldquoIt was really good and creative.The film can be viewed on YouTube at youtube watch vGl-sgqHmw

title: work-way-new-petrol-station-haddington
story: A metal frame for the development has been constructed at Haddington Retail Park, on the townrsquos western edge. The petrol station, which will also include a retail unit, was approved by East Lothian Council in October .The petrol station was proposed by Euro Garages Ltd EPICLtd.Haddingtonrsquos community council was among those asked for their opinion on the proposals.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThey have suggested that the developers should reduce the size of the convenience store attached to the petrol filling station as well as putting time restrictions on it until the potential impact of increased traffic flow and noise can be determined.ldquoConcern is also raised with regards to impact of the proposal on the vitality and viability of the town centre of Haddington.Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, welcomed the addition of a new petrol station.He said: ldquoThere has not been good competition for fuel in Haddington since the Ideal Garage closed.ldquoAlthough I do think our local Jet garage is run by a local family, for consumers it will probably be a good thing.Euro Garages declined to comment on the project. It is currently unclear when the petrol station could open or who would operate the facility.Meanwhile, construction work on a neighbouring site ndash rumoured to be for a Starbucks drive-thru ndash is continuing.The site, to the east of the newly opened retail park, was originally earmarked for a pub restaurant but plans never materialised. Instead, a coffee shop with outdoor seating area, proposed by Euro Garages, was approved in April .

title: east-lothian-christmas-lights-switch-ons-2021-timings-locations
story: Dunbar, East Linton, Haddington, North Berwick and Tranent are among those bringing a little bit of sparkle to residents.Dirletonrsquos Christmas tree will be put in place today , although there is no official switch-on event planned.It will be a distanced occasion for North Berwick residents when the Christmas lights are turned on at a virtual event on Saturday.The townrsquos community council invited residents to send photos and videos of their favourite North Berwick memories of the past year, which have been collated in a short film to share on Saturday.The link to watch the video will be available on Saturday from pm via the community councilrsquos Facebook page. A Facebook account is not necessary.For residents in Prestonpans, the Woods familyrsquos annual Christmas lights display will light up the town on Saturday at pm.The lights at the home, at  Longdykes Road, will be on every evening, .-pm, until January .The owners added that visitors should expect added surprises at the switch-on.No plans have been confirmed for the townrsquos main Christmas lights switch-on.Festive spirit will fill Dunbar town centre on Sunday with the townrsquos ldquobiggest display of Christmas lights.More than three hours of entertainment will be offered on High Street ahead of the .pm switch-on.Coronavirus restrictions have impacted the volunteersrsquo plans this year, including the ability to fundraise.Despite that, Graham Adams, chairman of Dunbar Christmas Lights committee, said volunteers had been working hard throughout the year to ensure there was a display the town could be proud of. He said: ldquoI think it is something the town needs just for a pick-me-up.ldquoIt will be the biggest display we have ever had.Entertainment starts at pm when a street market and fun rides open.Dance Discovery will perform while a street ceilidh with Graeme Armstrong Ceilidh Band and Lutrek Live Statues is also planned.Dalkeith and Monktonhall Brass Band will play while Starz Entertainment will also be on High Street.At .pm, the Rev Suzie Garrard Fletcher, minister of the parish of Dunglass, will give a ministerrsquos welcome before George Robertson, who led Dunbarrsquos community resilience team, and Dunbar Primary School pupil Lucy Brown are on hand to switch the lights on.A spokesperson for the Christmas lights team said: ldquoWe kindly ask that all visitors take measures to ensure they remain safe and well.A lucky schoolgirl will have the honour of ensuring East Linton is basking in a festive glow on Sunday. Eve Sutherland, a P pupil at the villagersquos primary school, won a competition to design a poster for the Christmas lights committee.The lights will be switched on at pm at The Square.A spokesperson for the Christmas lights group was delighted to see the switch-onafter last yearrsquos Covid-related cancellation.They said: ldquoThere will be stalls from pm, including a tombola, lucky dip, face painting, a lsquowine or waterrsquo stall, and a raffle for a luxury hamper of Christmas goodies. There will be mulled wine, Prosecco, beer or soft drinks, entertainment from the community choir and a film for the children.ldquoAll proceeds will go to the Christmas lights fund. Come and support the villagersquos effort to brighten up the Christmas period.Festive spirit will come alive in Haddington on Sunday when its Christmas lights are switched on.A virtual switch-on, which will be shown live on Facebook, is planned as concerns remain in place about the coronavirus pandemic.A Christmas tree is already in place outside the Corn Exchange, with plans for a second tree to be located in the Nungate.Graham Samuel, from the townrsquos community council, said the switch-on would take place at .pm and encouraged people to watch on the Haddington Events Grouprsquos Facebook page.The community councillor praised the work of the townrsquos volunteers, led by Steve Gibson, who ensure Haddington is sparkling each festive season.Residents of Tranent will also be surrounded by magical lights and the sound of Christmas carols when the townrsquos Christmas tree is lit up on Sunday evening.Tranent and Elphinstone Community Councilrsquos Christmas tree switch-on takes place between pm and pm at Winton Place, with attendees being welcomed with the sound of carol singing from the Clark Community Choir.Alcohol-free mulled wine and mince pies will be available after the switch-on at Thomsonrsquos on High Street.A living Christmas tree in Longniddry has been planted in the village however, no official switch on or parade will take place. Instead, the lights will be switched on at pm on Wednesday by community councillors.Meanwhile, other communities will be switching on their lights the following weekend.In Gford, the switch-on event is next Fridayat pm at the village hall. On the same day, Wallyfordrsquos Christmas lights are switched on, with a parade leaving from the minersrsquo club at .pm.Aberlady residents are being encouraged to switch on their outdoor Christmas lights at the same time next Saturdayat pm. The light-up event will be filmed by drone and shared to social media.And next Sunday , Cockenzie and Port Setonrsquos Christmas tree lights are switched on at the townrsquos harbour, at a time to be confirmed.But in Musselburgh there will be no torchlight parade or official ceremony this year due to a hold-up with delivery of materials to repair some of the lights. Once these have been delivered, the lights will be switched on at a date to be confirmed.Plans are still to be confirmed for any switch-on event in Gullane.

title: shops-closed-boxing-day-2021-scotland---see-full-list
story: With the increase in online shopping, lots of brands have decided to give their staff a well earned day off after Christmas.This includes some major supermarkets which is worth factoring in to your food shop before the big day so you can stock up on essentials.Heres what you need to know about which shops will be closed on Boxing Day ...In , many shops closed on BoxingDay as thank you to staff who had worked tirelessly through the pandemic.This year many stores will continue the new tradition of closing on December , giving employees a chance to take advantage of the festive break.Shops opening on Boxing Day has long been a controversial point, with a petition launched in  against shops opening on December  gathering over , signatures.The petition read: "Christmas is a family time, the one day is not enough time to see two sides of families, retail workers work extremely hard during the Christmas run up and only get the one day."If only everywhere could be closed boxing day! Some things are needed over the festive period, retail isnt one of them."It wasdebated in Parliament on December  , however the government concluded by saying: "We do not believe it is for the central Government to tell businesses how to run their shops or how best to serve their customers."Therefore we are not proposing to ban shops from opening on Boxing Day."
